content: quote: Originally posted by dmuhler: quote: Originally posted by threerings: quote: Originally posted by dmuhler: quote: Back in November of 08 McCain said that our economy is basically sound. A lot of things have changed since then (BILLIONS spent to shore up the system). McCain was wrong then, and I believe that Obama is correct now. Based on WHAT? Based on public record. Bernanke and Paulson both went before the leadership of congress in Sept of 08 and pronounced the system on the verge of collapse. It is important to keep in mind that both are republicans and were appointed by GW Bush. On Sunday Bernanke claimed we have turned the corner and that the economy is now recovering. The stress tests that are on going will confirm the soundness of the economy. I believe that he is correct. 2 words: Unemployment and Inflation. Right now the economy is being held up by the artifical injection of a massive amount of money..money we dont have. There has been no plan to deal with that debt. No plan to deal with the large number of umployed and no plan to slow the unthinkable level of money being printed at the moment.

title: Obama agrees with McCain

content: quote: Originally posted by 10tenths: I believe what he said is that we have averted a depression, but are still in recession (losing ground) and that we will turn that "corner" by the end of this year. Well ... sort of. He then went on to give himself a rabbit hole with a few caveats: quote: Bernanke, however, allowed some leeway in the optimism and confidence he expressed. "Recovery is not going to happen until the financial markets and the banks are stabilized," he said. He warned the nation's 8.1 percent unemployment would continue to rise. He also voiced concerns that the country might lack the political will to take further measures to stabilize the financial system, reiterating the call for an overhaul of the U.S. financial regulations. Bernanke did have every reason for such a reservation. For example, though the country agrees to reform the financial system and tighten financial supervision, its has been at odds on detailed measures. Also for those financial groups which claimed to be profitable, their profitability and how badly their assets have been hit by the crisis remain unknown. "The biggest risk is that we don't have the political will," said Bernanke. There's a danger that "we don't have the commitment to solve this problem, and that we let it just continue. In which case, we can't count on recovery," warned Bernanke. <more> "http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2009-03/17/content_11026430.htm" Seems to me that the Fed and Administration have gone from selling gloom-and-doom to blowing sunshine ... after finally recognizing that building confidence (warranted or not) is a key component of recovery.
quote: Originally posted by 10tenths: I believe what he said is that we have averted a depression, but are still in recession (losing ground) and that we will turn that "corner" by the end of this year.
reply: Well ... sort of. He then went on to give himself a rabbit hole with a few caveats: quote: Bernanke, however, allowed some leeway in the optimism and confidence he expressed. "Recovery is not going to happen until the financial markets and the banks are stabilized," he said. He warned the nation's 8.1 percent unemployment would continue to rise. He also voiced concerns that the country might lack the political will to take further measures to stabilize the financial system, reiterating the call for an overhaul of the U.S. financial regulations. Bernanke did have every reason for such a reservation. For example, though the country agrees to reform the financial system and tighten financial supervision, its has been at odds on detailed measures. Also for those financial groups which claimed to be profitable, their profitability and how badly their assets have been hit by the crisis remain unknown. "The biggest risk is that we don't have the political will," said Bernanke. There's a danger that "we don't have the commitment to solve this problem, and that we let it just continue. In which case, we can't count on recovery," warned Bernanke. <more> "http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2009-03/17/content_11026430.htm" Seems to me that the Fed and Administration have gone from selling gloom-and-doom to blowing sunshine ... after finally recognizing that building confidence (warranted or not) is a key component of recovery.

content: quote: Originally posted by dmuhler: quote: Originally posted by threerings: quote: Originally posted by dmuhler: quote: Back in November of 08 McCain said that our economy is basically sound. A lot of things have changed since then (BILLIONS spent to shore up the system). McCain was wrong then, and I believe that Obama is correct now. Based on WHAT? Based on public record. Bernanke and Paulson both went before the leadership of congress in Sept of 08 and pronounced the system on the verge of collapse. It is important to keep in mind that both are republicans and were appointed by GW Bush. On Sunday Bernanke claimed we have turned the corner and that the economy is now recovering. The stress tests that are on going will confirm the soundness of the economy. I believe that he is correct. 2 words: Unemployment and Inflation. Right now the economy is being held up by the artifical injection of a massive amount of money..money we dont have. There has been no plan to deal with that debt. No plan to deal with the large number of umployed and no plan to slow the unthinkable level of money being printed at the moment.

title: Obama agrees with McCain

content: quote: Originally posted by 10tenths: I believe what he said is that we have averted a depression, but are still in recession (losing ground) and that we will turn that "corner" by the end of this year. Well ... sort of. He then went on to give himself a rabbit hole with a few caveats: quote: Bernanke, however, allowed some leeway in the optimism and confidence he expressed. "Recovery is not going to happen until the financial markets and the banks are stabilized," he said. He warned the nation's 8.1 percent unemployment would continue to rise. He also voiced concerns that the country might lack the political will to take further measures to stabilize the financial system, reiterating the call for an overhaul of the U.S. financial regulations. Bernanke did have every reason for such a reservation. For example, though the country agrees to reform the financial system and tighten financial supervision, its has been at odds on detailed measures. Also for those financial groups which claimed to be profitable, their profitability and how badly their assets have been hit by the crisis remain unknown. "The biggest risk is that we don't have the political will," said Bernanke. There's a danger that "we don't have the commitment to solve this problem, and that we let it just continue. In which case, we can't count on recovery," warned Bernanke. <more> "http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2009-03/17/content_11026430.htm" Seems to me that the Fed and Administration have gone from selling gloom-and-doom to blowing sunshine ... after finally recognizing that building confidence (warranted or not) is a key component of recovery.
quote: Originally posted by 10tenths: I believe what he said is that we have averted a depression, but are still in recession (losing ground) and that we will turn that "corner" by the end of this year.
reply: Well ... sort of. He then went on to give himself a rabbit hole with a few caveats: quote: Bernanke, however, allowed some leeway in the optimism and confidence he expressed. "Recovery is not going to happen until the financial markets and the banks are stabilized," he said. He warned the nation's 8.1 percent unemployment would continue to rise. He also voiced concerns that the country might lack the political will to take further measures to stabilize the financial system, reiterating the call for an overhaul of the U.S. financial regulations. Bernanke did have every reason for such a reservation. For example, though the country agrees to reform the financial system and tighten financial supervision, its has been at odds on detailed measures. Also for those financial groups which claimed to be profitable, their profitability and how badly their assets have been hit by the crisis remain unknown. "The biggest risk is that we don't have the political will," said Bernanke. There's a danger that "we don't have the commitment to solve this problem, and that we let it just continue. In which case, we can't count on recovery," warned Bernanke. <more> "http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2009-03/17/content_11026430.htm" Seems to me that the Fed and Administration have gone from selling gloom-and-doom to blowing sunshine ... after finally recognizing that building confidence (warranted or not) is a key component of recovery.

content: quote: Originally posted by dmuhler: quote: Originally posted by threerings: quote: Originally posted by dmuhler: quote: Back in November of 08 McCain said that our economy is basically sound. A lot of things have changed since then (BILLIONS spent to shore up the system). McCain was wrong then, and I believe that Obama is correct now. Based on WHAT? Based on public record. Bernanke and Paulson both went before the leadership of congress in Sept of 08 and pronounced the system on the verge of collapse. It is important to keep in mind that both are republicans and were appointed by GW Bush. On Sunday Bernanke claimed we have turned the corner and that the economy is now recovering. The stress tests that are on going will confirm the soundness of the economy. I believe that he is correct. 2 words: Unemployment and Inflation. Right now the economy is being held up by the artifical injection of a massive amount of money..money we dont have. There has been no plan to deal with that debt. No plan to deal with the large number of umployed and no plan to slow the unthinkable level of money being printed at the moment.
quote: Originally posted by dmuhler: quote: Originally posted by threerings: quote: Originally posted by dmuhler: quote: Back in November of 08 McCain said that our economy is basically sound. A lot of things have changed since then (BILLIONS spent to shore up the system). McCain was wrong then, and I believe that Obama is correct now. Based on WHAT? Based on public record. Bernanke and Paulson both went before the leadership of congress in Sept of 08 and pronounced the system on the verge of collapse. It is important to keep in mind that both are republicans and were appointed by GW Bush. On Sunday Bernanke claimed we have turned the corner and that the economy is now recovering. The stress tests that are on going will confirm the soundness of the economy. I believe that he is correct.
reply: 2 words: Unemployment and Inflation. Right now the economy is being held up by the artifical injection of a massive amount of money..money we dont have. There has been no plan to deal with that debt. No plan to deal with the large number of umployed and no plan to slow the unthinkable level of money being printed at the moment.
title: Obama agrees with McCain

content: quote: Originally posted by 10tenths: I believe what he said is that we have averted a depression, but are still in recession (losing ground) and that we will turn that "corner" by the end of this year. Well ... sort of. He then went on to give himself a rabbit hole with a few caveats: quote: Bernanke, however, allowed some leeway in the optimism and confidence he expressed. "Recovery is not going to happen until the financial markets and the banks are stabilized," he said. He warned the nation's 8.1 percent unemployment would continue to rise. He also voiced concerns that the country might lack the political will to take further measures to stabilize the financial system, reiterating the call for an overhaul of the U.S. financial regulations. Bernanke did have every reason for such a reservation. For example, though the country agrees to reform the financial system and tighten financial supervision, its has been at odds on detailed measures. Also for those financial groups which claimed to be profitable, their profitability and how badly their assets have been hit by the crisis remain unknown. "The biggest risk is that we don't have the political will," said Bernanke. There's a danger that "we don't have the commitment to solve this problem, and that we let it just continue. In which case, we can't count on recovery," warned Bernanke. <more> "http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2009-03/17/content_11026430.htm" Seems to me that the Fed and Administration have gone from selling gloom-and-doom to blowing sunshine ... after finally recognizing that building confidence (warranted or not) is a key component of recovery.
quote: Originally posted by 10tenths: I believe what he said is that we have averted a depression, but are still in recession (losing ground) and that we will turn that "corner" by the end of this year.
reply: Well ... sort of. He then went on to give himself a rabbit hole with a few caveats: quote: Bernanke, however, allowed some leeway in the optimism and confidence he expressed. "Recovery is not going to happen until the financial markets and the banks are stabilized," he said. He warned the nation's 8.1 percent unemployment would continue to rise. He also voiced concerns that the country might lack the political will to take further measures to stabilize the financial system, reiterating the call for an overhaul of the U.S. financial regulations. Bernanke did have every reason for such a reservation. For example, though the country agrees to reform the financial system and tighten financial supervision, its has been at odds on detailed measures. Also for those financial groups which claimed to be profitable, their profitability and how badly their assets have been hit by the crisis remain unknown. "The biggest risk is that we don't have the political will," said Bernanke. There's a danger that "we don't have the commitment to solve this problem, and that we let it just continue. In which case, we can't count on recovery," warned Bernanke. <more> "http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2009-03/17/content_11026430.htm" Seems to me that the Fed and Administration have gone from selling gloom-and-doom to blowing sunshine ... after finally recognizing that building confidence (warranted or not) is a key component of recovery.
